text.*:
This article needs additional citations for verification. Please help improve this article by adding citations to reliable sources. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. (August 2017) (Learn how and when to remove this template message)

Contraindications to breastfeeding are those conditions that could compromise the health of the infant if breast milk from their mother is consumed. One example of this is galactosemia. This is. If the mother has HIV or antiviral therapy, untreated active tuberculosis, Human T-lymphotropic virus 1 or II, uses illicit drugs, or mothers undergoing chemotherapy or radiation treatment.[1][2]

Breastfeeding contradiction is an act of breastfeeding a child while the mother has conditions such as an addiction or disease. Breast milk contains many nutrients that formulas in store shelves do not have which makes breast feeding a healthier and ideal way to feed an infant.[3] Breastfeeding contraindications can occur if a mother does not take medication or seek medical advice prior to breast. The effects of the contradiction can do damage to both the infant and even the mother. It is important to explore the factors that can do damage that way a mother can be informed and well educated on the subject manner.[3]

Contents

  • 1 Addiction and Breastfeeding Contraindications
  • 2 HIV
  • 3 T cell lymphotropic virus type 1 and 2
  • 4 Alcohol
  • 5 References

Addiction and Breastfeeding Contraindications[edit]

Breastfeeding contradiction is an act of breastfeeding a child while the mother has conditions such as an addiction or disease. Breast milk contains many nutrients that formulas in store shelves do not have which makes breast feeding a healthier and ideal way to feed an infant.[4] Breastfeeding contraindications can occur if a mother does not take medication or seek medical advice prior to breast. The effects of the contradiction can do damage to both the infant and even the mother. It is important to explore the factors that can do damage that way a mother can be informed and well educated on the subject manner.[4]

HIV[edit]

Breastfeeding contradiction is an act of breastfeeding a child while the mother has conditions such as an addiction or disease. Breast milk contains many nutrients that formulas in store shelves do not have which makes breast feeding a healthier and ideal way to feed an infant.[5] Breastfeeding contraindications can occur if a mother does not take medication or seek medical advice prior to breast. The effects of the contradiction can do damage to both the infant and even the mother. It is important to explore the factors that can do damage that way a mother can be informed and well educated on the subject manner.[5]

T cell lymphotropic virus type 1 and 2[edit]

An individual with T cell lymphotropic virus type 1 and 2 will have excessive amounts of T-cell leukemia and HTLV-1. This often happens through the spread of needles and can affect anyone at any age.[6] If a mother contains this virus and is not aware of it the spread to her infant can be at an all time high of 25%.[6] There is currently no antivirals a mother can take to decrease the spread which is why breastfeeding is not recommended.[7]

Alcohol[edit]

Alcohol intake can also pose a threat to an infant, the fat content in your breast can cause toxins from alcohol to build up. It is advised that mothers only limit their drinking to one or two drinks a week so the spread of toxins does not reach the breast.[8] If a mother is binge drinking while breastfeeding and the toxins spread to the infant; there will be a risk of slow weight gain for the infant.[9]

References[edit]

  1. ^ Meek, Joan Younger; Hatcher, Amy J.; Breastfeeding, Section On (1 May 2017). "The Breastfeeding-Friendly Pediatric Office Practice". Pediatrics. 139 (5): e20170647. doi:10.1542/peds.2017-0647. PMID 28557776. Retrieved 6 August 2017 – via pediatrics.aappublications.org. 
  2. ^ "Diseases and Conditions - Breastfeeding - CDC". www.cdc.gov. Retrieved 6 August 2017. 
  3. ^ "Using Cocaine While Breastfeeding - DrugAbuse.com". drugabuse.com. Retrieved 2018-05-09. 
  4. ^ a b Slater, Mackenzie; Stringer, Elizabeth M.; Stringer, Jeffrey S. A. (2010). "Breastfeeding in HIV-positive women: What can be recommended?". Paediatric Drugs. 12 (1): 1–9. doi:10.2165/11316130-000000000-00000. ISSN 1179-2019. PMID 20034337. 
  5. ^ a b "Gale - Enter Product Login". link.galegroup.com. Retrieved 2018-05-09. 
  6. ^ a b Ribeiro, Maísa A.; Martins, Marina L.; Teixeira, Carolina; Ladeira, Roberto; Oliveira, Maria de Fátima; Januário, José Nélio; Proietti, Fernando A.; Carneiro-Proietti, Anna Bárbara de Freitas (November 2012). "Blocking vertical transmission of human T cell lymphotropic virus type 1 and 2 through breastfeeding interruption". The Pediatric Infectious Disease Journal. 31 (11): 1139–1143. doi:10.1097/INF.0b013e318263215e. ISSN 1532-0987. PMID 22683674. 
  7. ^ "Alcohol and breastfeeding - La Leche League GB". La Leche League GB. 2014-04-09. Retrieved 2018-05-09. 
  8. ^ "15 Things That Make Breastmilk Toxic". BabyGaga. 2016-10-21. Retrieved 2018-05-09. 
  9. ^ "Alcohol and breastfeeding - La Leche League GB". La Leche League GB. 2014-04-09. Retrieved 2018-05-10.
